Home / Videos / Interview with Tim Murphy at Software Craftsmanship North America 2012

Interview with Tim Murphy at Software Craftsmanship North America 2012

★ Transcript Available Jump to transcript
Description: Interview with Tim Murphy at Software Craftsmanship North America 2012 on community building and user-group organizing. The conversation captures practical lessons shared at the event.
Duration: 5 min · Published: Nov 26, 2012
Watch on Vimeo Watch on Youtube

Transcript

Hi, it’s Mike with UGtastic again. I’m sitting here at a SciTag meeting. What is SciTag? SciTag is the Chicago Information Technology Architects Group meeting, and I’m sitting here with Tim W. Murphy, @TWMurphy on Twitter, who runs the user group. Hi Tim, thanks for sitting down with me. Thank you. Can you tell me a little bit about what is SciTag? Well, Chicago Information Technology Architect Group, the whole long name that we’re officially required to have there because “architect” is a protected name within professions in Illinois. Okay. We have to call it “information technology” otherwise we could sue. Oh, really? We started in 2008, four of us that wanted to get together and discuss architecture-related topics, but we didn’t want to limit it to one particular topic. We had one particular practice within architecture. We essentially sit down with Microsoft people, Java people, Ruby, you name it. That’s what I was going to ask, is it focused on platform? We’re very agnostic as far as what platforms we cover. Now granted, the group that started the Architects Group was all Microsoft people. We had an architect, an architect, and a developer. I think that’s what we did. I think that’s what we did. We had an architect, an architect, an evangelist from Microsoft, Larry Clarkin, Carl Franklin from Maven Wave, and a gentleman from CBW, Steven Rylander. Carl and I are the only two that are left from the group at this point. Between shuffling our normal consulting jobs and trying to get speakers so that we can offer the Chicago community a view. A view into different technology topics that affect the way we architect solutions. So your talks are more like higher level, this is how we put together solutions, not so much implementation details. We vary. Some of them are very high level concept, and other ones, we’ve had a couple. One that we did last year was Java versus C#. So we went down into the code and more of an application architect level, and then we’ve had ones that were data architect or information architect driven. I’ve gone to one of your meetings before, but it was under a different name. What was the CAG? It was the Chicago Architects Group. Now when you kind of mentioned having to change a name, was that why? It was a Chicago Architects Group. It was a Chicago Architects Group. It was a Chicago Architects Group.
